etymologies: late Middle English (in relict (sense 2)): from Old French relicte ‘(woman) left behind’, from late Latin relicta, from the verb relinquere ‘leave behind’. relict (sense 1) arose in the early 20th century and is from Latin relictus, past participle of relinquere

definitions: a thing which has survived from an earlier period or in a primitive form.
shortDefinitions: thing which has survived from earlier period or in primitive form

definitions: an animal or plant that has survived while others of its group have become extinct, e.g. the coelacanth.
shortDefinitions: animal or plant that has survived while others of its group have become extinct

definitions: a species or community that formerly had a wider distribution but now survives in only a few localities such as refugia.
shortDefinitions: population that now survives in only few localities
